Spot the Signs. Take Action. Protect Lives.

What is Safeguarding?

Safeguarding means protecting the health, well-being, and human rights of individuals, especially vulnerable people, to live safely, free from abuse and neglect.

It applies in many settings — including schools, healthcare, social care, and communities — and involves identifying risks, taking action, and creating safe environments for everyone.

  • Protects children and adults at risk
  • Prevents harm and exploitation
  • Promotes safe and supportive environments
Learn more

Signs of Abuse

Emotional Abuse

Constant criticism, gaslighting, or isolating someone from friends and family.

Physical Abuse

Hitting, slapping, choking, or any physical harm intended to control or intimidate.

Sexual Abuse

Unwanted touching, coercion, or sexual contact without consent even in relationships.

Financial Abuse

Controlling money, limiting access to finances, or forcing someone into debt.

Coercive Control

Monitoring movements, isolating from support, or using threats to dominate.

Digital Abuse

Spying on messages, tracking location, or controlling online and social activity.

Take the Right Action

Simple steps you can take if you or someone else is at risk

In Immediate Danger

Call 999 or go to the nearest police station or A&E. Emergency services are trained to help.

More on Emergency Help
Talk to Someone

Speak to someone you trust like a friend, GP, teacher, or safeguarding officer.

Contact Childline
Report Anonymously

Use our anonymous form to report your concerns without revealing your identity.

Go to Form
Document What You See

If it’s safe, note down dates, times, and descriptions of any incidents.

NSPCC Advice
Use Support Apps

Apps like Bright Sky offer advice, diary logs, and local support info.

Explore Bright Sky
Learn the Signs

Recognising signs of abuse is the first step to helping someone in need.

View Common Signs
Reach Out to Services

Contact safeguarding teams, support helplines, or charities for help.

Get Support
Protect Your Privacy

Clear your browser history and keep personal info safe when researching help.

How to Stay Safe Online

Get Help and Support

  • Police or Ambulance: Call 999
  • 24/7 National Domestic Abuse Helpline: 0808 2000 247
  • Samaritans: 116 123 (free and confidential)
  • Bright Sky App: Free app for finding local support — Download Bright Sky

  • Clare’s Law: Request info on a partner's abusive past
  • DAPOs (Protection Orders)
  • Report abuse via gov.uk
  • Women’s Aid | Men’s Advice Line

If you're concerned about the safety or wellbeing of an adult, you can contact your local Safeguarding Adults Board:

  • Search via the Ann Craft Trust website

  • Mind: mind.org.uk
  • Samaritans: 116 123 | samaritans.org
  • Rethink: rethink.org
  • Childline: 0800 1111 | childline.org.uk

If you’re worried about someone’s safety but want to remain anonymous, you can still report your concerns.

Go to Anonymous Report Form
